body:
The class-cast exception could come about if one mixes incompatible bitmap factories. If tracking them down is a problem, some helper functions could be added.

@fjy  Nice milestone.

@fjy : The error on query is because compression strategy doesn't seem to be either persisted or loaded from the column metadata correctly. It looks like IndexIO simply uses whatever the server default is, rather than detecting the version.

Yes I'm aware.
On Nov 10, 2014 8:01 AM, "Charles Allen" notifications@github.com wrote:

> @fjy https://github.com/fjy : The error on query is because compression
> strategy doesn't seem to be either persisted or loaded from the column
> metadata correctly. It looks like IndexIO simply uses whatever the server
> default is, rather than detecting the version.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/833#issuecomment-62405785.
And I'm a moron, this was the wrong pull for that comment :)
any numbers on how much this improves performance?

Ran some performance tests.

On straight up topN, there seems to be no improvements. For filtered topN there may or may not be improvements, lots of time is still spend in the aggregation. On topN with a regex filter, there is a ~20% improvement in execution time when using roaring.

The resulting SMOOSH size is about 10% larger for roaring. for [TPC-H data](http://www.tpc.org/tpch/)
@lemire : Working on getting it better scripted :) once I have a setup like @xvrl 's R-based benchmarking I'll be more confident in the overall results.

General performance improvements:

TopN multivalue multi aggregate: just shy of 30% faster

TopN multivalue single aggregate: just shy of 5% faster

Some benchmark results against a TPC-H sample are below. Please note this should be considered a general datapoint and very likely not applicable to all data sources.

# Dataset ingestion spec

## Concise Bitmap Compression


## R code

```
library(RDruid)
library(microbenchmark)
library(ggplot2)
library(magrittr)

druid <- druid.url("localhost", 8081)
int <- interval(ymd(19800101), ymd(20200101))

# For some reason these won't import correctly for me
druid.filter <- function(...) new("druid.filter", ...)

druid.build.filter <- function(type, ...) {
  druid.filter(list(type = type, ...))
}

druid.filter.selector <- function(dimension, value) {
  druid.build.filter("selector", dimension = dimension, value = value)
}



doubleSum <- function(dataSource) druid.query.timeseries(
  url = druid,
  dataSource  = dataSource,
  intervals    = int,
  granularity = "all",
  aggregations = list(
    sum    = sum(metric("L_DISCOUNT"))
  ),
  verbose=F,
  context = list(useCache=F, populateCache=F)
)


doubleSumTopN <- function(dataSource) druid.query.topN(
  url = druid,
  dataSource  = dataSource,
  intervals    = int,
  aggregations = list(
    sum    = sum(metric("L_DISCOUNT"))
  ),
  metric = "sum",
  dimension = "l_comment",
  n = 100,
  verbose=F,
  context = list(useCache=F, populateCache=F)
)



topN_regex <- function(dataSource) druid.query.topN(
  url = druid,
  dataSource  = dataSource,
  intervals    = int,
  aggregations = list(
    sum    = sum(metric("l_tax")),
    sum1   = sum(metric("L_DISCOUNT")),
    sum2   = sum(metric("L_EXTENDEDPRICE")),
    sum3   = sum(metric("L_QUANTITY")),
    count  = druid.count()
  ),
  filter = druid.filter.regex("l_comment",".*e.*"),
  metric = "sum",
  dimension = "l_comment",
  n = 100,
  verbose=F,
  context = list(useCache=F, populateCache=F)
)


bench <- microbenchmark(
  topN_regex("test_lz4_high"),
  topN_regex("test_roaring_second_sv"),
  doubleSumTopN("test_lz4_high"),
  doubleSumTopN("test_roaring_second_sv"),
  doubleSum("test_lz4_high"),
  doubleSum("test_roaring_second_sv"),
  doubleSumTopN_filtered("test_lz4_high"),
  doubleSumTopN_filtered("test_roaring_second_sv"),
  doubleSum_filtered("test_lz4_high"),
  doubleSum_filtered("test_roaring_second_sv"),
  times=10
)
```

## Results

Unit: milliseconds

| expr | min | lq | mean | median | uq | max | neval |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| topN_regex("test_lz4_high") | 38217.4111 | 38375.5502 | 39487.5855 | 39656.5683 | 39993.9743 | 40885.1137 | 10 |
| topN_regex("test_roaring_second_sv") | 33240.2808 | 33433.2509 | 34169.5983 | 34121.9430 | 34802.3043 | 35322.433 | 10 |
| doubleSumTopN("test_lz4_high") | 2727.5786 | 2822.3171 | 2922.0883 | 2928.6425 | 3040.5825 | 3141.4699 | 10 |
| doubleSumTopN("test_roaring_second_sv") | 2744.4852 | 2765.7417 | 2839.1427 | 2800.9751 | 2926.7100 | 2983.7123 | 10 |
| doubleSum("test_lz4_high") | 142.8893 | 147.0413 | 155.4532 | 152.9560 | 168.6678 | 173.3427 | 10 |
| doubleSum("test_roaring_second_sv") | 144.5505 | 152.1636 | 161.4037 | 160.1929 | 170.4770 | 182.6104 | 10 |
| doubleSumTopN_filtered("test_lz4_high") | 3003.2968 | 3024.4974 | 3200.8764 | 3217.2591 | 3263.9874 | 3518.7261 | 10 |
| doubleSumTopN_filtered("test_roaring_second_sv") | 2870.4791 | 2918.0627 | 3104.6641 | 3169.1757 | 3208.9683 | 3313.3643 | 10 |
| doubleSum_filtered("test_lz4_high") | 383.1903 | 421.0811 | 463.4273 | 480.7985 | 503.4525 | 537.8297 | 10 |
| doubleSum_filtered("test_roaring_second_sv") | 282.7707 | 305.3039 | 322.6563 | 327.4737 | 342.1256 | 351.0571 | 10 |

## Sizes

```
-rw-r--r--  1 charlesallen  wheel        572 Nov 10 16:09 meta.smoosh
-rw-r--r--  1 charlesallen  wheel          4 Nov 10 16:09 version.bin
```

## Summary of TPC-H sample
- Sizes of the SMOOSH tends to be about 10% larger for Roaring vs Concise.
- Simple topN and timeseries queries seem unaffected by changes in underlying bitmap representation.
- topN over regex filters have a significant improvement (~20%) in execution time when using Roaring over Concise.
- topN with 10 filter conditions OR'ed together yields a small but notable (~3%) improvement in execution time
- Simple time series with 10 filter conditions OR'ed together can yield a significant ( up to ~30%) improvement in execution time.

The above benchmark was performed on my OSX - Yosimite macbook pro running a 2.5GHz i7.

```
$ java -version
java version "1.7.0_71"
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.7.0_71-b14)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 24.71-b01, mixed mode)
```

```
-Ddruid.zk.service.host=localhost
-Ddruid.db.connector.connectURI="jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/druid"
-Ddruid.db.connector.user=druid
-Ddruid.db.connector.user=diurd

-Ddruid.storage.storage.storageDirectory=/Users/charlesallen/bin/wrk/storage
-Ddruid.emitter=noop
-Ddruid.processing.numThreads=1
```

The CPU frequency governor is set on "kid in a candy store" so all time-based results are going to have significant variance simply due to shifts in CPU frequency.

@drcrallen  

Thanks.

One has to assess how much does the bitmap computation accounts for the total running time. If bitmap computations account for 40% of the total running time, and you see a 20% overall gain, then this would, indeed, correspond to a 2x performance gain in bitmap processing speed. (This is hypothetical, of course.)

This being said, the performance characteristics of roaring are really quite different from concise, so the fact that you see no difference at all in several cases suggest that maybe the bitmap computations are not a bottleneck in these cases... Maybe the bulk of the running time is spent doing things other than bitmap processing in these cases... 

In any case, it would be very useful to have some kind of idea about how much of these tests rely on bitmap speed. They are small enough, it seems, that IO costs are many not a major issue... 

Some kind of profiling would be great... Do you have guys have any good experiences profiling Druid? Do you use any tools? In other projects, I have used JProfiler, but I have never approached something quite as big as Druid.

As for storage space, we have documented cases where concise compresses better than roaring: when the data is dominated by long consecutive sequences all around. This was the case in one of our data sets, Wikileaks, where we got a percentage of difference with storage costs close to the one you report. (See our paper http://arxiv.org/abs/1402.6407) We did not worry about such cases because we still offered a significant speed gain with roaring. It would be relatively easy to do a more thorough analysis to explain the storage use... for example, review the bitmaps generated and their relative sizes in roaring and concise vs. their characteristics. This could inform further work.

Hi!

Thanks for the contrib! Before I can merge the pull request, we need you to
agree to our CLA. In the repo there is an individual CLA and a corporate
CLA. If you are working on your own behalf and agree to the CLA, responding
here with a comment of "I agree to the terms of the Druid Individual CLA as
it exists in the current master branch" is sufficient. If you are working on
behalf of a company, can you have your company fill out the corporate CLA
and submit it to us? Thanks again!
All, this is getting closed down to merge to Master instead.
Reopened @ https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/848
Closing to re-submit against master
Closing to merge with master instead.
Closing this to re-open another pull request to Master
Batch announcement should be the default in 0.7. Sounds like we have the default value defined in multiple places.

Actually I think I didn't understand the problem. There isn't currently a race, because the callbacks and the merge/pushing all happen in the mergeExecutor's single thread. But there is a problem with queued up merge/pushes getting borked by abandons triggered from the server view callbacks. So that can be addressed by checking for segment abandonment before actually beginning the merge/push, once it starts running in the thread. (The single thread bottleneck would act as sort of a de facto lock)
If someone picks this up, be careful re: #812

what issue are you having?
@xvrl segments were failing to load because the FileUtils.deleteDirectory call was doing really weird stuff.
Basically no segments would load on the historical. If you could get a fresh copy of 0.6.x and see if you also have the problem I'd appreciate it.

In case someone is searching for it later, here's the error:


```
/tmp/druid/indexCache/test_roaring2/1980-01-01T00:00:00.000Z_2020-01-01T00:00:00.000Z/2014-11-13T16:28:52.965Z/0/downloadStartMarker is not a directory
```

some test would be nice
@gianm I'm having a hard time reproducing the error. Can you please describe the steps you expect to have taken to encounter the error in terms of plumber calls?

We spoke in person but the gist of it was that what happens is:
- Segment is announced
- Segment is merged, pushed, and published
- Segment is unannounced and abandoned (due to server view callback)
- Plumber tries to merge, push, and publish the segment again, because another task was in the queue to do that. This fails due to abandonment of the segment. In the indexing service this manifests as a lock violation, since "unannounce" releases the lock but "publish" requires a lock. I'm not sure what happens in standalone realtime.

Hi Prashant, looking over some Druid code, if you have two real-time nodes
ingesting data with different segment granularities completely overlapping,
queries will fail. You need to shut down one of the real-time nodes before
things resolve themselves. This was an oversight on my part in suggesting
the 2 nodes in parallel. If you want to change segment granularity, it
cannot be done without downtime.

> If you want to change segment granularity, it
> cannot be done without downtime.

How much downtime? just one hour to do the switch or a full day?

Let's say you do this:

Real-time node A: starts at T00:00:000Z (hourly)
Real-time node B: starts at T00:00:000Z (daily)

For any queries from T00 to T01, queries will fail. At any time you shut
down realtime A, queries should work again.

The issue was caused by a null being fed into the InputStream queue on rare occasions. The added check seems to have fixed this.

Druid 0.7 now requires the name on the wrapped aggregator and ignores any name passed on the outer.
Druid since 0.6.162 now defaults to the name of the wrapped aggregator, but optionally allows to override it using the outer aggregator for backwards compatibility.
can we create a PR for 0.6.x as well?
@xvrl is there a way to add a unit test for this?
we could try refactoring the code to make it testable, but I think we need a proper integration test to see if query timeouts get propagated.
